Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Unattended/Automated Studies of Effects of Auditory Distractions on Users Performing Security-Critical Tasks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
User errors or delays while performing security-critical tasks can lead to undesirable or even disastrous consequences. The impact of both accidental and intentional distractions on users in such situations has received little investigation. In particular, it is unclear whether and how sensory stimuli (e.g., sound or light) influence users' behavior and trigger mistakes. Better understanding of the effects of such distractions can lead to increased user awareness and countermeasures. Preliminary studies suggest somewhat surprising effects of auditory distractions; this project develops an unattended study allowing more rigorous evaluation of the impact of distractions.

The project conducts controlled user studies to examine the effects of different sound variations on participants' speed and accuracy when logging into a computer network, controlling for participants' awareness of the distraction event. Existing theory suggests auditory distractions can both improve and degrade performance; this will be carefully evaluated to determine how various stimuli impact security actions. The experiments will be conducted in a fully automated manner, which makes large-scale studies feasible and also avoids any potential experimenter bias.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project conducted controlled user studies to examine the effects of different light and sound variations on subjects’ speed and accuracy when performing security-critical tasks (such as logging into a computer network), while at the same time controlling for subjects’ awareness of the distraction event. Existing theory of perception suggests auditory stimuli can both improve and degrade performance. This will has been carefully evaluated to determine how various stimuli impact security-related actions. The experiments were conducted in a fully automated manner, which made a series of large-scale studies feasible and also avoided any potential experimenter bias.

More specifically, we focused on exploring the impact of unexpected auditory and visual stimuli on subjects paring two Bluetooth devices, solving CAPTCHAs, and responding to a two-factor authentication challenge. This is carrying forward from previous work on the effect of similar stimuli on subject performance in Bluetooth pairing. From this work, we were able to identify a relationship between overall sensory arousal and subject performance in these tasks reminiscent of the Yerkes-Dodson curve for complex tasks.

Overall, we found that sensory stimulation exhibits a spectrum of effects on subjects performing security-critical tasks. In general, subjects performing these tasks without any additional stimulation perform in a sub-optimal manner. This performance can be improved by the introduction of a carefully-crafted stimulus that induces only a small amount of sensory arousal. However, this performance improvement is only observed for the simplest of stimuli. For example, the sound of a babbling brook was shown to increase the speed of subjects successfully completing CAPTCHA challenges by 25%. When more complex audio stimuli are administered, subjects instead experienced a negative impact. In particular, subjects exposed to rapidly-varying “looming” sounds that were created to simulate the sounds of an approaching unknown object were shown to have a stark negative impact on subject task performance, roughly doubling the rate of error for attempting CAPTCHA challenges.

Furthermore, we have found merit in the unattended experimental paradigm. In addition to allowing for a homogenous subject experience that removes any potential for experimenter bias, we have observed that subject performance in such a setting is comparable to performance in a more traditional attended setting. This allows for the rapid deployment of large-scale user studies without the required investment in person-power traditionally associated with a wide-ranging study such as ours. In fact, we were able to evaluate over 500 subjects over the lifetime of this project without requiring any real-time experimenter involvement or the costs associated with such.

Over the duration of this project, we presented interim results in several poster sessions through UCI’s Institute for Software Research. Additionally, several manuscripts describing this work were made, including one detailing the impact of visual stimuli on Bluetooth Pairing that was accepted to The 15th International Conference on Applied Cryptography and Network Security (ACNS2017), Kanazawa, Japan. A manuscript describing the impact of both auditory and visual stimuli on Bluetooth Paring was published in the November/December 2017 issue of IEEE Security & Privacy. Additionally, a manuscript detailing the impact of auditory stimuli on subjects solving CAPTCHA challenges has been prepared and is currently in submission at the 19th Privacy Enhancing Technologies Symposium (PETS 2019).
